1{-# LANGUAGE ScopedTypeVariables #-}
2{-# OPTIONS_GHC -Wall #-}
3
4-- | Fundamental operators in relational algebra.
5--
6--   Tropashko's relational lattice is a kind of relational algebra.
7--   Relational algebra is an algebraic formulation for relational model.
8--   In constrast to Codd's original relational algebra,
9--   Tropashko lattice is in more conventional and strict ways.
10--   The lattice has fundamental operators from which
11--   other operators are derived.
12
13module Koshucode.Baala.Rop.Flat.Lattice.Tropashko
14  ( -- * Fundamental operators
15    -- $FundamentalOperators
16  
17    -- * meet (natural join)
18    consMeet,
19    relmapMeet,
20    relkitMeet,
21    -- $MeetImplementation
22  
23    -- * join (inner union)
24    consJoin,
25    relmapJoin,
26    relmapJoinList,
27    relkitJoin,
28
29    -- * Check shared terms
30    SharedTerms,
31    unmatchShare,
32  ) where
33
34import qualified Koshucode.Baala.Base               as B
35import qualified Koshucode.Baala.Syntax             as S
36import qualified Koshucode.Baala.Data               as D
37import qualified Koshucode.Baala.Core               as C
38import qualified Koshucode.Baala.Rop.Base           as Op
39import qualified Koshucode.Baala.Rop.Flat.Message   as Msg
40
41
42-- ----------------------  meet
43
44-- | Construct relmap to meet relation.
45consMeet :: (Ord c) => C.RopCons c
46consMeet med =
47  do rmap <- Op.getRelmap med "-relmap"
48     sh   <- Op.getMaybe Op.getTerms med "-share"
49     Right $ relmapMeet med sh rmap
50
51-- | Meet two relations.
52relmapMeet :: (Ord c)
53    => C.Intmed c          -- ^ Source infomation
54    -> SharedTerms         -- ^ Shared terms
55    -> C.Relmap c          -- ^ Subrelmap of meet operator
56    -> C.Relmap c          -- ^ Relmap of meet operator
57relmapMeet med sh = C.relmapBinary med $ relkitMeet sh
58
59-- | Meet two relations.
60relkitMeet :: forall c. (Ord c) => SharedTerms -> C.RelkitBinary c
61relkitMeet sh (C.Relkit _ (Just he2) kitb2) (Just he1) = kit3 where
62    lr     = D.termPicker he1 he2
63    he3    = he2 B.<> he1
64    kit3   = case unmatchShare sh lr of
65               Nothing     -> Right $ C.relkitJust he3 $ C.RelkitAbFull False kitf3 [kitb2]
66               Just (e, a) -> Msg.unmatchShare e a
67
68    kitf3 :: [C.BodyMap c] -> C.BodyMap c
69    kitf3 bmaps bo1 =
70        do let [bmap2] = bmaps
71           bo2 <- bmap2 bo1
72           case D.ssLShareIndex lr of
73             [] -> Right $ cartesian bo1 bo2
74             _  -> let b2map = B.gatherToMap $ map (D.ssRSplit lr) bo2
75                   in Right $ step b2map `concatMap` bo1
76
77    step b2map cs1 = case D.ssLShare lr cs1 `B.lookupMap` b2map of
78                       Just b2side -> map (++ cs1) b2side
79                       Nothing     -> []
80
81relkitMeet _ _ _ = Right C.relkitNothing
82
83cartesian :: [[c]] -> [[c]] -> [[c]]
84cartesian bo1 bo2 =
85    do cs1 <- bo1
86       cs2 <- bo2
87       return $ cs2 ++ cs1
88
89
90-- ----------------------  join
91
92-- | Construct relmap to join relation.
93consJoin :: (Ord c) => C.RopCons c
94consJoin med =
95    do rmap <- Op.getRelmap med "-relmap"
96       sh   <- Op.getMaybe Op.getTerms med "-share"
97       Right $ relmapJoin med sh rmap
98
99-- | Join two relations.
100relmapJoin
101    :: (Ord c)
102    => C.Intmed c          -- ^ Source infomation
103    -> SharedTerms         -- ^ Shared terms
104    -> C.Relmap c          -- ^ Subrelmap of join operator
105    -> C.Relmap c          -- ^ Relmap of join operator
106relmapJoin med sh = C.relmapBinary med $ relkitJoin sh
107
108-- | Join multiple relations.
109relmapJoinList :: (Ord c) => C.Intmed c -> [C.Relmap c] -> C.Relmap c
110relmapJoinList med [] = C.relmapConst med D.reldau
111relmapJoinList _ [rmap] = rmap
112relmapJoinList med (rmap : rmaps) = rmap B.<> rmaps' where
113    rmaps' = relmapJoin med Nothing $ relmapJoinList med rmaps
114
115-- | Join two relations.
116relkitJoin :: SharedTerms -> C.RelkitBinary c
117relkitJoin sh (C.Relkit _ (Just he2) kitb2) (Just he1) = kit3 where
118    lr     = D.termPicker he1 he2
119    he3    = D.ssLShare lr `D.headMap` he1
120    kit3   = case unmatchShare sh lr of
121               Nothing     -> Right $ C.relkitJust he3 $ C.RelkitAbFull True kitf3 [kitb2]
122               Just (e, a) -> Msg.unmatchShare e a
123
124    kitf3 :: [C.BodyMap c] -> C.BodyMap c
125    kitf3 bmaps bo1 =
126        do let [bmap2] = bmaps
127               left    = map $ D.ssLShare lr
128               right   = map $ D.ssRShare lr
129           bo2 <- bmap2 bo1
130           Right $ left bo1 ++ right bo2
131
132relkitJoin _ _ _ = Right C.relkitNothing
133
134
135-- ----------------------  Check shared terms
136
137-- | Shared terms for composing check.
138type SharedTerms = Maybe [S.TermName]
139
140-- | Calculate unmatch shared terms.
141unmatchShare :: SharedTerms -> D.TermPicker c -> Maybe ([S.TermName], [S.TermName])
142unmatchShare (Nothing) _ = Nothing
143unmatchShare (Just sh) lr =
144    let e = B.setList sh
145        a = B.setList $ D.ssRShareNames lr
146    in if e == a
147       then Nothing
148       else Just (e, a)
149
150
151-- ------------------------------------------------------------------
152-- $FundamentalOperators
153--
154--    In lattice theory, there are two operators /meet/ and /join/.
155--
156--    [R1 ^ R2]  Meet of /R1/ and /R2/.
157--               This operator is one of generalized intersection,
158--               as it were, a more-speaking-and-less-mentioning operation.
159--               ''Meet'' is same as ''natural join'' in SQL.
160--               /R1/ tuple is meetable to /R2/ tuple if and only if
161--               shared terms of /R1/ tuple and /R2/ tuple
162--               are same contents.
163--
164--    [R1 v R2]  Join of /R1/ and /R2/.
165--               This operator is one of generalized union,
166--               as it were, a less-speaking-and-more-mentioning operation.
167--               Toropashko calls it ''inner union''.
168--               Join of /R1/ and /R2/ is ordinary union of
169--               shared-term-projection tuples in /R1/ and /R2/.
170--
171
172-- ------------------------------------------------------------------
173-- $MeetImplementation
174--
175--    Summary of calculating meet of relations like
176--    @(\/a \/b \/c)@ meet @(\/b \/c \/d)@ = @(\/d ++ \/a \/b \/c)@.
177--    In this case, shared terms are @\/b@ and @\/c@,
178--    left-sided term is @\/a@, and right-sided term is @\/d@.
179--
180--    [Input]    Relations @(Rel he1 bo1)@ and @(Rel he2 bo2)@
181--
182--    [Output]   Relation @(Rel he3 b3)@
183--
184--    1. Let @s1@ be shared-term information of @he1@.
185--
186--    2. Let @s2@ be shared-term information of @he2@.
187--
188--    3. Let @cs1@ :: @[c]@ be element of @bo1@.
189--
190--    4. Let @cs2@ :: @[c]@ be element of @bo2@.
191--
192--    5. Split each @cs2@, by @s2@,
193--       into shared and sided terms :: @([c], [c])@.
194--
195--    6. For each same shared terms, collect the sided terms.
196--       Let it be @(share2, sides2)@ :: @([c], [[c]])@.
197--
198--    7. Pick shared terms @share1@ :: @[c]@,
199--       by @s1@, from each @cs1@.
200--
201--    8. Concat @cs1@ and each of @sides2@
202--       where @share1@ equals @share2@,
203--
204
